item.title: Reported Russian strikes in Ukraine - 16:00 GMT https://t.co/l26BsB8gWe https://t.co/hajCzbxtP9
The war in Ukraine will test Turkey’s relationship with Russia, possibly to destruction https://t.co/OEorKc0Qq5
The war in Ukraine will test Turkey’s relationship with Russia, possibly to destruction https://t.co/aHAHpMbfxm
Vladimir Putin seemingly covets all of Ukraine, just as British and American intelligence reports claimed all along https://t.co/z1s9oq71k5

There had been speculation that the president might be satisfied with control over Donetsk and Luhansk, two small, Russian-backed enclaves of Ukraine. All that has crumpled in the face of a vast assault https://t.co/mS9BFSeIVT
China drew closer to Russia on the eve of war. Will President Xi Jinping come to regret it? https://t.co/0FhPt54odA
Few countries are watching the war with Ukraine as anxiously as Turkey. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is eager to preserve a recent rapprochement with Russia https://t.co/6dCcTwTv9u
Since the cold war, western European countries have tended to shrug off this nasty side of Gazprom. Instead they have become overdependent on its gas https://t.co/Et7Qk5IR7L

♦️ Ukrainian officials say Russia has seized the former Chernobyl power plant.
♦️ Russia carried out more than 200 attacks on Thursday, Ukraine said.
♦️ Officials in Ukraine called for Russia to be cut off from the SWIFT payment system.
Catch up on the latest developments👇
Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s president, has declared martial law and promised to give weapons to any citizen willing to defend the country https://t.co/mA3M0bYw2Q
For months as Vladimir Putin amassed troops on Ukraine’s borders the question had been: what does he want? Now it is: where will he stop? https://t.co/qXcRmAXXCP
Missiles have struck across the country, and troops have poured in from the north, east and south https://t.co/Y3BbSrHAKB
Our coverage explains what’s at stake, what lies behind Vladimir Putin’s thinking and what might happen next https://t.co/oI8FsLfyJW

My latest in the @TheEconomist on the risk of escalation in the Russia-Ukraine war
https://t.co/CTaHFYxDyu
Russia’s presence in mining has sent metal prices skyward. Palladium, nickel, aluminium and copper, all of which it produces, have leapt this year https://t.co/5VZCrCrjFu
We’ve mapped where Russian strikes have been reported, and where troops have crossed into Ukraine https://t.co/iqRXTCu5Cv

♦️ Volodymyr Zelensky said Russian troops were trying to seize the former Chernobyl power plant.
♦️ The EU plans sanctions against Russian banks and tech.
♦️ Lithuania declared a state of emergency; Moldova’s government called for one.
Stay up to date on the war in Ukraine👇
Chillingly, Vladimir Putin all but threatened nuclear escalation against the West after America and its allies sent additional troops to reinforce the eastern flank of NATO https://t.co/ODV0h0CyqI
Republicans are playing a more constructive role in the Ukraine crisis than Donald Trump must like https://t.co/fEFDy1mMEX
The war in Ukraine will shake Vladimir Putin’s regime to its foundations and shatter assumptions about European security https://t.co/hkbAOECQyJ
The war will result in the isolation of the world’s 11th-largest economy and one of its largest commodity producers https://t.co/8Vpth98D1A
Fear and defiance grip the citizens of Ukraine’s capital as Russia’s attack begins https://t.co/FBWkpjZpLc
In the fighting and the misery that is to come, much Ukrainian and Russian blood will be spilled. Every drop of it will be splattered on Vladimir Putin’s hands https://t.co/6vzMBBfM0R
The economic consequences of the war in Ukraine https://t.co/NFpE9zIL5E
“The mood is split between those who want to get out and those who will offer a fight.” As Russia’s invasion begins, @olliecarroll talks to “The Intelligence” from Ukraine https://t.co/tnqNQmptpk
Where will he stop? https://t.co/0ajdp9mguH

Stephen Hadley, Bush's former NSA, told us about his concerns around Kaliningrad: “If Putin succeeds in Ukraine, he might decide that he needs a land bridge to link Kaliningrad to Belarus and then Russia...through Lithuania or Poland”. https://t.co/2CklcX56eL

♦️ The West considers how far Russia will go to subdue Ukraine.
♦️ Ukrainians flee for safety. Poland and Germany prepare to receive refugees.
♦️ NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg says Russia has “shattered” peace in Europe.
Catch up with the latest developments 👇

Within minutes of Vladimir Putin declaring war on Ukraine, explosions were heard near Kyiv’s main airport, as well as in many other cities. This map details them.
We explain what led to the conflict, and what could happen next ⬇️
Nothing about this war was inevitable. It is a conflict entirely of Vladimir Putin’s own making https://t.co/3SJGZDdXaw
Oil is above $100 a barrel. Wheat is up 20% since the start of this year. Natural gas rose 30% in early trading. Prices have leapt as Russia goes to war https://t.co/GJLh9q7rW5

People are gathering to watch the latest updates. Many have huddled in one of the deepest underground transit systems in the world. Others are stocking up on supplies. Meanwhile the routes out of Kyiv are closing https://t.co/gNmJmiKBW6
Russia has never accepted Ukrainian independence. We explain the history of the forced brotherhood between the two countries https://t.co/pyBaHAfBBh

Invading Ukraine could ultimately prove Vladimir Putin’s undoing, we wrote in a recent article, if it turns into a bloody quagmire or makes Russians poorer, angrier and more eager for change https://t.co/DjvtkDvSaN

Nothing about the war in Ukraine was inevitable. It is a conflict entirely of Vladimir Putin’s own making. Our cover story explains why, and how, the world must inflict a heavy price for his aggression https://t.co/qvYmymAfFA https://t.co/hwCZjB74oY

Russia was not threatened by NATO or Ukraine. Its invasion of the sovereign state next door is a war of choice, conjured out of nothing by Vladimir Putin. History will judge him harshly https://t.co/tbB1Rzrj2h

In parts of Ukraine, people woke to the sound of sirens and took to their basements; elsewhere some knelt on the streets to pray. People rushed to withdraw cash as huge traffic jams formed on the roads out of Kyiv https://t.co/DXfa4C4dT4
Wars unfold in unpredictable ways. Recently we explained why Russia’s aim would probably be to hurt Ukraine, not occupy it https://t.co/vESQYNsK0A
“A lot of my friends have left this morning.” The routes out of Kyiv are closing. The government has shut down Ukrainian airspace. We report from the capital https://t.co/npWHr46hgq
Ukrainians have woken up to the worst news imaginable. We report on the mood in Kyiv https://t.co/vF0RvFDq22
A war that many thought unthinkable has begun. It will reshape European security https://t.co/DwSw5HvBsk

Donetsk and Luhansk, part of the Donbas region dominated by Russian-speakers, have since 2014 been controlled by separatists and so, in effect, by Russia. We explain why these regions matter https://t.co/uDcUomv2x0
Ensuring that any contact points with Ukraine and Russia are not a vulnerability for the rest of their operations is the first of many steps that firms should take https://t.co/GluT6baJFR
Anxious messages in group chats and families divided: not all Ukrainians have been feeling the same way about the threat of war https://t.co/bQZAm1HIwu

Video evidence appears to show Russian troops crossing the border into Ukraine from both Crimea in the south and Belarus in the north.
Catch up with the latest developments 👇
The threat of war in Ukraine has been evoking long-standing fears across the region, as we explained recently https://t.co/yXtdTQsLCT

Vladimir Putin has declared war on Ukraine. We are following the conflict closely.
Learn what’s at stake and what might happen next ⬇️
Since the cold war, western European countries have tended to shrug off this nasty side of Gazprom. Instead they have become overdependent on its gas https://t.co/xtjycbEhLQ

Why can’t Russia accept Ukraine’s independence?
Our film explains. Watch here ⬇️

The origins of the crisis lie in 2014, when an uprising toppled Viktor Yanukovych, Ukraine’s then president. Since then, as Ukraine’s government turned to the West for political and military support, Vladimir Putin has grown more hostile https://t.co/QX4DbIr0xW
